blog.name: cleowho
blog.title: Flight Through Eternity
blog.description:
Classic Doctor Who / Contemporary Doctor Who blog by Chloe "Cleo" Mortimer.
British fan girl and obsessive Whonatic. Tweets @CleoWho
All posts created exclusively by me unless they're marked as reblogs. Expect SPOILERS, because you can't enthuse over fifty years of a TV show and keep everything that's happened a secret.
Comments and opinions are entirely my own. Original text entries are copyright (c) Chloe Mortimer.

summary: Behind the Scene of The Waters of Mars (Part 12) Excerpt from The Radio Times article on The Waters of Mars (by Benjamin Cook):...
caption:
Behind the Scene of The Waters of Mars (Part 12)

Excerpt from The Radio Times article on The Waters of Mars (by Benjamin Cook):

“I was utterly thrilled when I read the script and saw where it was going,” says David Tennant. “The Doctor is more fallible than we’ve ever seen him before. It was such a brilliant notion, and very bold.”  How will younger viewers respond? “I don’t know, actually. It’ll be interesting to see. To challenge children with that is great - to show that their heroes can be conflicted. It’s good to see the Doctor wobble. Only when this Doctor’s story is coming to an end can you be as bold. We couldn’t have done it at any other time, and Matt [Smith, Tennant’s successor] and Steven [Moffat, showrunner from 2010] can’t do that when they start. It’s only in extremis that you can allow the character to unravel a bit. Fantastic to play.”

Any suggestion that The Waters of Mars puts Doctor Who firmly in the “no longer a children’s show” category is vehemently rebuffed by [Russell T] Davies [showrunner & co-author of the episode]. “Tough moral dilemmas are meat and drink for kids. It’s exactly the sort of stuff we should feed them with. We’re failing them if we don’t.” Even in a story with scary monsters and a fallible Doctor? “The darkest scares come from children’s stories. Our fear of the dark, of forests, strange noises, and empty houses - that’s all the stuff of childhood. It’s healthy stuff. It’s the stuff we love, both at the time and in hindsight.

“Childhood isn’t a time of eternal smiles; when you’re a kid, you cry as much as you laugh. The best children’s literature demonstrates this. What Harry Potter goes through with his own mum and dad is more intense than anything the Doctor encounters with a bunch of Martian colonists. It’s the parents who worry. The kids will be holding mum’s hand, saying it’s going to be all right!”

Other Waters of Mars behind-the-scenes posts: [ one ] [ two ] [ three ] [ four ] [ five ] [ six ] [ seven ] [ eight ] [ nine ] [ ten ]

title: Doctor Who Review - New Earth
body:
This is one of those episodes that I’ve changed my opinion on, but not to any major degree. I can really see the strengths of this episode that I didn’t before, but I can also more easily idenify the key reason that this one doesn’t really work.

Before I rewatched it, I thought New Earth was that strange, unfunny, body-swap story in the hospital. I thought it lacked depth, characterisation for any non-returning characters, and really any point. But now, through one key realisation, this is completely different, and instead of being average because it’s uninspired, this one’s bad because it took a marvelous premise that had the promise of depth and a moral dilemma and simply added Cassandra to include comedy, which subsequently took up the majority of the episode in the place of the zombie-like patients and the cat-nuns. (as a sidenote, I don’t actually dislike the cat-nuns, I just think that they’re underutilised every time the appear)

The idea of a hospital that has created life to experiment on and that these people have escaped, looking for revenge on those who wronged them is a wonderful science-fiction idea. The cat-nuns have tried to find a solution where none of their patients have to die, but as a result there are thousands of illness-ridden life forms that are killed and recycled to find impossible solutions to uncurable diseases. The cat-nuns seem to think that they’ve done nothing wrong, and it’s up to the Doctor and Rose to convince them that the monstrosities that have been created can be cured so that they can find a way to save the city of New New York. If you really want, you can have a villain that is in charge of the hospital just to make a profit, and finds it impossible to see the flaws in their plans until the entire hospital is overrun, or perhaps setting them loose as part of yet another elaborate insurance scam, and slowly learning the error of their ways as they beging to understand their creations. That’s how I would play this. Instead, Cassandra is also trying to investigate what the cats are doing for unspecified reasons and mostly provides comic relief through the body-swapping shennanigains. The cats present their case at the start, but then they dissappear until the very end, when one of them glares at the Doctor while being arrested. They never have a proper debate about it, nor do they learn the error of their ways. Cassandra does get a moment to realise what has happened to the illness people when she needs to possess one of them, but that doesn’t really mean anything besides her realising that they’re people, not just an army for her to release (but that doesn’t really make sense because that wasn’t made a plot point in the episode). Oh and then the Doctor solves it all by pouring every medicine they have in that one room into a bucket and pouring it onto the ill people.

4/10 So much promise, but they picked the wrong tone

summary: I just told my 15 year old aunt the names of David Tennant and Georgia's (I can't remember how to spell her last name even...
body:
I just told my 15 year old aunt the names of David Tennant and Georgia’s (I can’t remember how to spell her last name even though I read it like two minutes ago) kids and she then came up with a scenario.

David: honey, where did you get this tie?

Georgia: I don’t remember. But, its a really lovely colour. An olive tie. It suits you.

David: oh my god, we should name some of our kids, Olive and Ty!!

I actually think they’re really nice names and so are Wilfred and Doris.

tags: David Tennant's face is a problem for me
I have so many photos from this panel because I was too busy watching him
and just kept the button pressed on my camera
But that also means I also have a lot of duds
But these were a handful of my favorites

summary: Another dream come true for me today. A big hug from the loving arms of David Tennant. Saw him at Megacon Orlando and it was...
body: Another dream come true for me today. A big hug from the loving arms of David Tennant. Saw him at Megacon Orlando and it was beyond great. Life doesn’t get much better than it was today!!

reblog.comment: Another dream come true for me today. A big hug from the loving arms of David Tennant. Saw him at Megacon Orlando and it was beyond great. Life doesn’t get much better than it was today!!

trail.content_raw: Another dream come true for me today. A big hug from the loving arms of David Tennant. Saw him at Megacon Orlando and it was beyond great. Life doesn’t get much better than it was today!!
trail.content: Another dream come true for me today. A big hug from the loving arms of David Tennant. Saw him at Megacon Orlando and it was beyond great. Life doesn’t get much better than it was today!!

blog.description:
hi everyone!!!!! my name is ali and i love lord of the rings, game of thrones, star wars, star trek, harry potter, doctor who, hunger games, etc.
im 22. sadly working an adult job in aviation, 
i love going to disney, universal, seaworld
this blog is just all about my life and my interest. 
follow me!!
